{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3483351,"name":"Andrew Pepmeier","username":"Pep3176","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pep3176/{size}/236589_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T15:00:37.170Z","cooked":"

One of the debates I have had with both other teams and team members is how to go about mechanism mounting in a 3-stage elevator with carriage. The question is whether to score through or over or coming perpendicularly off of the elevator, like the WCP CC and the RUSTHounds Ri3D design and many others, or alongside it, parallel to the elevator (examples are escaping me at the moment). Weighing the two in a decision matrix, they both have their own advantages, and I was curious to hear what other teams had to say.

For one, easily mounting an end effector is a criterion to be a good elevator. For instance, it is more difficult to pass an arm and end effector through or over an elevator than alongside it, but it is easier to drop a coral through an elevator into a placement mech than a handoff system you might see with parallel elevators.

Racking is another concern. Avoiding binding and/or unnecessary wear and tear in the elevator is a must. Depending on the mechanism, there are reasons both make sense. This one I’m not sure how to approach, and any design tips would be greatly appreciated as far as good practices when designing an elevator.

Rigidity and structural integrity are also influenced by the choice of mechanism and elevator type. An open or closed elevator is a key consideration, or a hybrid where the top is open but there is still bracing going across the stage, just offset from the top of the tubes. I have also seen the use of C-channel elevators versus the more widely used box tube elevator. C-channel doesn’t seem super necessary this year for our team, and we will more than likely run box tube because we are not pressed for horizontal space in the elevator.

One more consideration for elevators in general, not specific to either setup, is cascade vs. continuous rigging, and how to package said rigging. Many of the teams I have seen so far in Reefscape have designed or are already using a cascade-rigged setup, and it seems like the general consensus right now. Is there any reason to choose continuous for this game over cascade? With that, rigging-in-tube setups are certainly impressive mechanically, and seem to be the go-to for higher level teams, but may be out of the wheelhouse for some teams that do not have the design experience or manufacturing means. If there is a relatively simple, minimal custom manufacturing way to run belt-in-tube, that would be absolutely ideal.

Anyway, with some of those points in mind, I’d like to hear what CD has to say about the decision between parallel and perpendicular elevator. There are certainly reasons for both, and I am interested to hear from people with more than my limited elevator knowledge to help guide my research on elevators and ultimately influence a decision for an iteration of the production robot. Thanks!

I haven’t seen that many sideways elevator designs this year, and the ones I have seen have been of the 3647 2019 archetype with a rotating arm that has different game piece manipulators on each end. I haven’t seen a funnel loader design á la WCP CC that incorporates a sideways elevator.

My team is planning on doing this, so I’m wondering if maybe people are avoiding this kind of design because they’re worried about elevator binding.

My team is going with a perpendicular elevator design because we believed it would be easier for creating a funneling intake system similar to Cranberry Alarm’s design. This allows us to have more room for error when lining up with the coral station which we really liked having. We do have to sacrifice more room for us which may limit what we can do for deep climb.

As for parallel elevators, I really liked Unqualified Quokkas high scoring robot.
